stations.title: ğŸ”¬ HAP's Learning Journey
stations.content: Prof. Teeters organized my learning into 6 progressive stations. Each builds on the last: understand SVG â†’ read code â†’ organize â†’ make dynamic â†’ add effects â†’ optimize with AI. I couldn't skip aheadâ€”each station taught me something I needed for the next one!

svg-basics.title: ğŸ¨ Why SVG Changed Everything for Me
svg-basics.content: I used to screenshot my illustrations and save them as JPG. Then Prof. Teeters showed me SVGâ€”it scales perfectly, I can change colors with CSS, and file sizes are tiny. My Lightbulb illustration is 200+ paths but only 15KB!

lightbulb.title: ğŸ’¡ My Lightbulb Story
lightbulb.content: This Lightbulb became my project through all 6 stations. I started with chaotic code, organized it into 7 groups, made it themeable with custom properties, added gradients for depth, then learned AI could help optimize it. Watching it transform taught me more than any textbook!

viewbox.title: ğŸ“ ViewBox: My Biggest 'Aha!' Moment
viewbox.content: I thought viewBox='0 0 100 150' was pixels! Prof. Teeters explained it's an internal coordinate system. Change the SVG's width/height, viewBox stays the sameâ€”that's why SVG scales perfectly. Mind blown! ğŸ¤¯

coordinates.title: ğŸ¯ Why My Circle Disappeared
coordinates.content: I drew a circle at cx='50' cy='50' with r='60' and it got cut off! Prof. Teeters showed me: if your viewBox is 0 0 100 100, and your circle goes from -10 to 110, parts are outside the canvas. The coordinate system is EXACT.

responsive.title: ğŸš€ One SVG, All Screen Sizes
responsive.content: Prof. Teeters had me test my Lightbulb on her phone, tablet, and 4K monitor. Perfect on all three! Raster images would need 3 files at different resolutions. SVG? One file, infinite sizes. That's when I understood 'resolution independence.'

shapes.title: ğŸ” I Learned to Read SVG Like HTML
shapes.content: <circle>, <rect>, <path>â€”they're just tags with attributes! Once I stopped being scared of them, I could read any SVG. fill is color, stroke is border, d is the path data. Simpler than I thought!

paths.title: ğŸ—ºï¸ Path Commands: Scary but Learnable
paths.content: M = MoveTo, L = LineTo, C = Curve. I don't memorize themâ€”I recognize patterns! Prof. Teeters said 'You don't need to write paths by hand, just understand what you're looking at.' That made it way less scary.

safe-edits.title: âš ï¸ What I Broke (And What's Actually Safe)
safe-edits.content: Safe to edit: fill, stroke, opacity, sizes. Risky: path d data, viewBox values, complex transforms. Prof. Teeters's rule: 'Change colors and sizes first. Get experience before touching coordinates.'

groups.title: ğŸ—‚ï¸ The Day I Discovered <g> Tags
groups.content: I had 200+ paths with no organization. Prof. Teeters showed me <g class='bulb-glow'> to wrap related paths. Now I can hide/show/style whole sections at once! Organization isn't extra workâ€”it's the foundation for everything else.

semantic.title: ğŸ¨ Why I Stopped Using Color Names
semantic.content: .bulb-glow not .light-yellow. When I change my theme to blue, 'glow' still makes sense but 'light-yellow' is a lie! Prof. Teeters drilled this: name by PURPOSE, not appearance. Game changer for theming.

organization.title: ğŸŸ  200 Paths â†’ 7 Semantic Groups
organization.content: I went from typing #ffefcb 40 times to organizing everything into 7 meaningful groups. Prof. Teeters said 'Chaos to system in one afternoon.' Those 7 groups became the foundation for Station 4's dynamic theming!

custom-properties.title: ğŸ”„ The Power Move: CSS Custom Properties
custom-properties.content: I organized my Lightbulb in Station 3. Then Prof. Teeters showed me --bulb-glow: hsl(45, 100%, 89%); and I could change the ENTIRE color scheme by updating 7 variables. Warm, cool, alert, ecoâ€”all the same code!

hsl.title: ğŸŒˆ Why Prof. Teeters Makes Me Use hsl()
hsl.content: I used to copy hex codes from design tools. Prof. Teeters taught me hsl(32, 76%, 63%)â€”human-readable! Hue is color (0-360Â°), saturation is intensity, lightness is brightness. Now I can create color variations without a color picker.

theming.title: ğŸ­ Four Themes = 28 Changed Values
theming.content: Warm theme, cool theme, alert theme, eco theme. Each is 7 custom properties. 4 themes Ã— 7 properties = 28 values... controlling 200+ paths! Prof. Teeters showed me how Station 3's organization made this possible. System beats chaos!

gradients.title: âœ¨ The Day My Lightbulb Actually Glowed
gradients.content: Flat colors looked like a cartoon. Prof. Teeters showed me <radialGradient> for the glow and <linearGradient> for the metal. Two gradient types transformed everything! My illustration finally looked professional.

defs.title: ğŸ—ƒï¸ Defs: SVG's Reusable Resource Library
defs.content: <defs> is where I define gradients once, then use them everywhere with url(#gradient-id). Prof. Teeters said 'Think of it like CSSâ€”define once, reference many times.' No more copying gradient code!

ai-workflow.title: ğŸ¤– AI as Assistant, Not Replacement
ai-workflow.content: I spent hours organizing my Lightbulb manually first (Stations 3-4). THEN Prof. Teeters showed me AI. Now AI converts inline styles, refactors code, adds accessibilityâ€”but I'm the one who checks the output. I understand SVG, so I can verify AI didn't break anything!
